div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier.
div.p: De "L'Egyptian Gazette"

Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de l' "Egyptian Gazette" paraît chaque Samed à midi, de façon à pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs; les dernières statistiques jusqu'à la veille de sa publication: des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc
L'abonnement pour une année en Egypte coûte 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste; pour l'étranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.

div.head: ASIA MINOR AND MESOPOTAMIA.
div.p: At an opportune moment there has appear ed an intelligible plea for the Baghdad Railway and for appreciation of the natare and spirit of that German enterprise it is to be foand in the October number of the "Edinburgh Review". The writer abandons for a moment that na tional point of view which, necessary though its acceptance is for the purpose of construe tive purpose of constructive policy, ought never to obscure the larger survey for which his torical study should prepare the statesman. He endeavours to conmder the future of Asia Minor and of Mesopotamia from an examina tion of their past and present condition. We shall attempt to trace the outlines of his thought. In the history of mankind and of its relations to the earth as ite dwelling place there is no contrast so striking as that between the ancient and the modern conditions of the countries between the Bosphorus and the Persian Gulf. Asia Minor from the age of Croesus to that of Diocletian, was a rich and populous and highly civilised country. Its map is covered with the names of towns familiar to all readers of pagan of Christian story, towns which to-day are not only ruined but covered by the dust and earth of centuries. From Troy to Tarrus from Halicarnassas to Trebizond, most of the cities have gone and are known only either by the map, by ruins too great to have been entirely buried, or by the excava tions of modern scholars. In northern Syria, beyonf the Taurus, were some of the most splendid cities of the Graco-Roman world, of which only the names and sometimes a modern town, the remains of some city of the early Calphs are to-day the representatives. From the Gulf of Alexandria to the East coast of the Persian Gulf there runs a great sweep of mountains enclosing a vast plain, watered by the two great rivers that flow southwards from the northern part of the mountain wall, where it supports the highlands of Armenia, and by their tributaries from the ridges of Western Persia. This plain was probably the cradle of civilisation. In the earliest times of which records and monuments are preserved it was the seat of a rich agriculture cherished by a settled government. It has gradually lost its population and its productivity. The rich crops were due not only to a diligent agriculture but also to a systematic and intelligent administra tion, ruling the whole region and carrying irrigation to a degree of excellence that has since never been surpassed, perhaps never been equalled. The decay of government which began long before Alexander and became rapid as the Roman Empire weakened has brought with it the neglect of the canals, the ruin of agricul ture, and the disappearance of population. These contrasts of conditions have had their parallels through not their equals. Egypt, Algeria, and Morocco were in the ancient world civilised and prosperous counries, and Egypt had an agriculture based upon irriga tion which at one time rivialled that of Meso potamia. But there is also a modern contrasr suggesting a new analogy.

The complete decay of all the counrties to which reference has been made dates from the decline of the Ottoman Empire in which they were all included. That Empire long ago lost all power of effcient administarion, and the countries where it was most at home were those that decayed the most. Two of them have in modern times been restroed to a new prosperity, which may in time rival that attested by the

ancient records. In Egypt first the French and afterwards the English have restored in turn the idea of civilisation and the order due to settled and efficient government. In Ailgerna the French have carried on a similar task which they would tike to undertake in Morocco also. Both nations in these enterprises have left themselves to be and have been recognised as the missionaries of European civilisation to countries tuat were mach in need of it. The attention of Germany, fully equal in her civilisation and her energy for its propagation to either of them, has had her attention direct ed towards Asiatic Turkey. This is no new thing it dates from the reign of Sultan Mabmoed II who engaged German officers to aasist him in reforming his army, officers who were among be early scientific explorers of Asin Minor and Mesopotamia, and whe have been followed by a long succession of geographical and historical pinoneers. The result has been that Germany hae taken & growing interest io Asia Minor and Mesopotamia, has heen represented by many fruitful researches of every kind, and has in recent years attempted in various ways that "peaceful penetration" of which England and France have given so many examples. Thus it has come about that German men of business have of late years taken the lead in developing the network of railways in Asia Minor. They have been helped, no doubt, by the policy of the German Government, just as English and French private enterprise in Egypt and Algeria has benefited through the policy of the British and French Governments. Why should not Germany by the "peaceful penetration" of Turkey in Asia attempt to restore some of the ancient prosperity of Asin Minor and of Meso potamia ! That is the question put, and it seems to us rightly put, by the "Edinbergh Review"

Those who have asked themselves what the justification of the British Empire have found that the answer mast be that Great Britain has the mission of taking order to countries where there was none, and of thus rendering possible in those countries a better life than was to be found or could exist before her advent. The civilisation she has is Euro pean. It has been gained in a thousand years of membership of the European commanity in India and in Egypt Great Britain in the mediator between European civilisation and populations that had lost the power of govern nent. It is a mission ot which no Power can have a monopoly. That France should be Eng land's fellow worker, each in its own sphere, has long been well understood Why not Ger many also ! That is the question put by the "Edinbergh Review" The only reasonable, the only intelligible, reply is, Why not! It may be true that with German commercial and industrial enterprise are associated German national ambitions. But that kind of associa tion is nataral and right. It exists in the case of England in Egypt and of France in Algeria Tunis, and Morocco. By all means then let our countrymen reconsider in the light of this question that of British relations with Ger many. In that way it may be possible to find that mach of the friction of recent years is lue to the over-tension of national feeling rritated, it matters little how, and degenerat ng, as it is prone to do, into Chauvinism. If the Germans can reproduce in Mesopotamia the cornfields of the Babylonians, as, accord ing to Sir William Willcocks whose report confirms the suggestions of the 'Edinbergh "Review" it is quite possible for them to do, they will benefit both Turkey and Great Britain, and are entitied also reap some benefit themselves

div.head: QUEEN TEIF'S MUMMY
div.p: With reference to the visit ot Mr. Thomlore M. Davis to Egypt. where he intends to bave what remains of the supposed mummy of (Queen Teie thorouglily investigated, Professor Sayce writes to the "Times" -—

"The bistorical difficulties seem to me to exclude the possibility of the body of a young man of twenty-five years of age being that of the 'Heretic King.' Moreover, if my copy of the inscription on the coffin ia cor rect, it would bave been 'made for the Queen' by Khu-n-Aten. I may, of course, have mis- copied the hieroglyphs in the obscure light of the tomb . Mr. Davis, however, confirms my reading. Bat as the coffin ix now in the maosenm at Cairo, thisis a point which can be cleared up at once

"Personally, I agree with Dr Elliot Smith in believing that the tomb has been restored hy one of Khu-n-Aten's suceeassur- do not see any other way of acconnting tor the fact (not otherwise noticed. apparently that the clay tablets found in it comme morate the King and not his mother

div.head: AMERICAN FINANCIAL CRISIS
div.p: CORTELYOU TO THE RESCUE
NEW YORK TRUST COMPANY
PITTSBURG EXCHANGE CLOSED
(Gazette s Special Service.)
London, Thursday
The American financial crisis has developed into a panic
Yesterday, thanks to the efforts of Mr. Cor telyou, Secretary to the Tresaury, it was hoped that the worst was over
The run on the New York Trust Company continued, but at the closing hour all depesi tors bad been paid in full
It is anticipated that the Trust Company will weather the storm
Mr Cortelyou says that he thinks the worst is over and expects that today will wind up the present episode.
There should not have been such trouble and excitement, there being no reason for these runs on hanks and tet companies In short, people have lost their heads.
As regards gold shipments to New York the opinion here this morning is hopeful and it is considered that they will not be necessary to any great extent.
All financial authorities realise the import ance of maintaining the reserve in the Bank of England
Receivers, have heen appointed for the Westinghouse allied companies
The Pittsburg Stock Exchange was closed yesterday
Should the panic extend thronghout the states, then the consequences would he terri bly serious.
So far, the London Stock Exchange has net been mueh affected and the commitments here are very small
(Gazette's Special Service.)
London, Friday.
The situation in AMerica is getting better, but the crisis has not yet passed away. The assistance afforded by Mr. Cortelyou and the millionaires is much appreciated
The Stock Exchange at Pittsburg still remains closed.
Yesterday's failures were unimportant

div.head: GOODS TRAIN DERAILED
div.p: Serious Delay of Mail

During the early hours of this morning a goods train on the Alexandria-Cairo line was derailed at Saft el Melouk by collision with a bale of cotton which had fallen from an earlier train. In consequence of this accident the night mail train from Cairo, which is due at Alexandria at 6 a.m., was delayed four and a half hours, while trains due here at 9.15 and 11 a.m. did not arrive until 11.07 and 11.30 a.m. respectively. Though perhaps somewhat too early to pass an opinion, it seems to us that a derailment within such a short distance of Tantah, a divisional centre, should not have necessitated so long a delay of what is in relaity the most important train of the day. inasmuchas it is the carrier of the heaviest mail. The delay of such a train seriously handicaps the work of all local busniness firms communicating with the capital, towns of the province, Upper Egypt and the Sudan and we trust that a strict enquiry will be made into the cause of the accident and the steps taken to clear the line

div.head: PORTS AND LIGHTOUSES ADMINISTRATION
div.p: The action brought by Mr. Albert Simha, late director of Stores of the Ports and Lighthouses Administration at Alexandria against the Egyptian Government is expected to come in for hearings next month. Mr. Simha claims that he has been unjustly dismissed from the service of the Government by the Committee of Enquiry and that the Government has no right to confiscate his pension. He also claims L.E. 1,000 damages adn the public acknowlegdement of his offical integrity by the Government. Maitre Mercinier will represent the plantiff

div.head: THE MURDER OF KING
div.p: Cannon was this morning brought before the British Consular Court on the charge of having murdered King, as reported in our issue of yesterday. Several witnesses from the "Baku Standard" were called, and it was deposed by the captain that when he was called and examined King he considered him sober. The case will be brought before the Supreme Consualr Court next month. At the inquest which was held yesterday the jury found that King, a fireman of Austrailian nationality, of the S.S. "Baku Standard", had met his death by a knife wound inflicted by Cannon. Dr. Morrison stated that death must have been almost instantaneous

div.head: THE CALABRIAN EARTHQUAKE
div.p: RELIEF MEASURES TAKEN
TERRIBLE LOSS OF LIFE
WHOLE TOWN DESTROYED
(Gazette's Special Service)

The latest reports of the earthquake in Southern Italy show that the loss to life and property throughout Calabria has been terrible. The Italian Government is sending pecuniary aid as well as material assistance to the suf ferers
200 persons are declared to have perished The fine Cathedral st Gerace has been de molished and the town of Perrnzzano completely destroyed

div.head: THE NATIONALIST PROGRAMME
div.p: The following is the programme ot Mestapha Pasha Kamel's cliqne as enunciated in his recent speech —

1.—The autonomy of Egypt (or her internal independence) as established in 1840 by the treaty of London and guaranteed by internal firmans. (This autonomy gearantees the throne of Egypt to the descendants of Mohamed Ali and the internal independence of the country it comprises all the countries given to Egypt by the Imperial firmans). This autonomy England has officially promised to respect
2. —The institution of representative govern ment, so that the governing authority may be responsible to Parliament possessing eetior. ity like that of European parliaments

3.—The respect of treaties and financial conventions which bind the Egyptian govern. ment to pay its debts and to accept a fimancial control like the Anglo French condominium, so long as Egypt remains the detter of Europe Lowboy, Friday aud Europe demands this control

4 —The outspoken criticism of all ill courses and actions, the recognition and emoourage ment of the good, and the demonstration to the Government of the interests of the nation, of its desires and the reformsof which it stands in need

5 — The furtherance and spreading of educa ion throughout the entire country on a strongly national basis, so that the poor may have the largest share . war against errors and stupidi ties the propagation of sound religious princ iples which inculcate progress, and the incitement of the rich and influential to aid education by foanding universities, by sending tmiasions to Europe and by creating night schools for the working classes
6. The development of agriculture,industry, commerce, and all the branches of social lite, in order to enable the nation to win scientific and economic independence

7 The entightenment of the minds of the Egyptians regarding the present situation, the propagation of the nationat spirit, the inculs- tion of union and harmony between the two the Copta,the indication of the duties incumbent on all towards their country and the accom plishment of these duties while taking care to assure peace and security im every nook and corner of Egypt

8. —The encouragement and assistance of every useful project and the amelioration of the sanitary conditions now prevailing, s that the inhabitants may increase in numbers and lin that manner augment the strength of the nation.
9. — The development of the bonds of union and frendship between Egyptians and the forergn colonists, the effacement of all misunderestanding and the judging of foreign criminals by the Mixed COurts

10.- The strengthening of the ties of friend ship of attachment between Egypt and the Ottoman Empire, the development of the re lations of friendship and confidence between Egypt and the European Powers, the refutation of all accusations framed against Egypt, and the winning over to the national cause of partisans everywhere, so that they may constitute a superior moral force, helping the nation to gain recongition by others of its legitamte rights and to foil the attempts made against its interests to hide the truth

div.head: LETERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: WILFRED SCAWEN BLUNT.
To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette."
Dear Sir, —How angry we all got here at the mention of Mr. Wiltred Blunt's name. We call him a liar, a traitor to his country, a Little Englander and all sorts of inharmonious things.

And now his book, which, by the way, you deseribe in your issue of Wednesday, as a last ing disgrace to the hand that penned it, if he try to read it in an extra parochial spirit shall we not find that, after all, however, mistaiten Mr. Blunt may have been, in our opinidin, as to the merit ot the movement at the head of which Arabi Pasim found himself, he was, at least, perfectly sincere, perfectly disinterested, absolutely untiring in his efforts to voice what he thought he recognised as the inarticulate cry for freedom of an oppressed people and that, after Tel el Rebir, he did not spare him self in his efforts to see that fairplay, of which we English claim the monopoly, was obtained for Arabi

And whilst we gather round the village pump perhaps somebody from the great world will step by and beg us bear in mind that Mr. Wiltred Blant, the poet the dreamer, the distinguished littératear was in 1881 and 1889, the period in connection with which, we here, can hardly think of him without gnaahing' of teeth, was, in London society, a prominent figure and amoch sought after guest in hbere, where, had he been the blood-stained traitor ot our imagination, he would surely not have beed admitted.

Having realised this, it may help nsto more homane view of Mr. Wilfred Blunt and we may even some to recognise him as a bene- factor and erect statues to Arabi Pasha and himself in our market-place, Wécnuse, after all, should we be here to-day, filling lucrative posts and makihg our forthnes on the Bourse if it were not for Arabi Pasha and his zealous porter Mr Witfted Stawen Blunt
Yours faithfally Alfted Lambart Sheykh Obevd Garden,October 24

div.head: THE "EGYPTIAN STANDARD"
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette."

Sir, —The recent extraordinary revolutions on the staff of the "Egyptian Standard" de serve some notice especially as considerable mystery appears to he connected with the posi tion of Mr Rady, the editor of Mustapha Pasha Kemel's English organ. That newspaper in its issue of Sanday last made the following annomncement
"The rumour circulated by certain papers that Mr Charles Rody had remgned his posi tion on the staff of the "Egyptan Standard" are antounded
The French edition od Kamel's organ on the same day declared

'La senle modification apportée & be rédar tion de notre confrére angiam constvte dans la Romination de Osman effendi Sabri comme secrétaire respormable lm direction « penaé que la responsabilité dun jourmal égyptien devait sppattemr « une personnatité égyp- tienne Mais la situation de M.C. Ruvty ren lest _nallement modifite. Bt lea notes tendan cieuses de confréres mal mformés dont certains out peu amicanx et dont tel se platt A der wee ordeuriores, valent tout juste la peine d'un dément catégorique.
Yet another French newspaper in an article on Mr Rody remarks —

"Nous ne sommes pas étonnés des marvais procedés dont il est victime. Nous pournons nous réjonir de la détermination de Moustapba Kamel qui le prive d'un collaboratear intelli gent etactit si nous n'avions sa apprécier comme elles te méritent la courtowe partaite et la lbonme camarederie dun contrére qui a en san quérir Yestin## de tous ceux qu'il a approchds

Et nous tenons 4 protester contre les prooé dés brutaux de ces politiciens prétentieux qui ne servent de l'esprt et du talent des autres jet qui ne savent méme pas lex récompenser de lear dévowvement par quelques égards"

What is the exact position of affairs M. Saint Ogan, theeditor of the Pasha's French paper, went off very soon after his appointment and now mysterines developments appear to have arisen in regard to the editor of his Eng lish organ Is the Pasha alone responsible for these cliangés and have the shareholders im the "Standard" no vowe at all in the matter. It seems as though the object of the Pasha is to make a nice, little tamily party in these concerns, al! his re lations beigg put into positions There ia first of all Kamel as Director Then we have his brother, Ali Bey Fahmy Manager of "Al Lewa" The Pasha has now appointed his brother in law, aman Effendi Sabri, as "responsible secretary" of the "Standard" and put his English editor Mr Rady, in a position of inferionty to this man. It is rumored in the purtiens of the Sharia el Daweweeh that the Pasha is contemplatng the appointmerit of another of his brothers, Hassan Bey Pabmy, who so it is said, will replace Mr. Maloney on the "Standard" at an early date. These persons are paid by the shareholders in the "Standard" and it seeins an excellent business for the Kamel family' bat what about the dividends
I am, Sir. Truly yours. "An Enquirer"
Cairo,October 22

div.head: RAILWAY TIME TABLE.
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette."

Sir,— I am an ardent reader of your wide- spread paper. Amoungst the important articles I so often read I encountered lately the name of Mr. Dunlop, the Adviser to the Minister of Education. This gentleman has been attacked by some people that seem to be eprsistant to their old habits, and consequentl, are adverse to seeing the postion of young Egyptian betttered in this futurre

From the short time of my staying in this country, I see that other reforms are urgently needed and this time in the Egyptian State Railways. I am in possession of a printed timetbale and strange it may seem to be that it obliges me to refer to my friends or to just ask either my servant, a barbarine, or stop some individual in the streets just to explain to me the name of the different stations, mostly those where I happen to be proceeding to. The timetable in question, allow me to mention is a puzzle in itself and a laughing stock to both Britisher and some foreigners English speaking, most especially to the innmerable tourists flocking in this country every winter aye all the year round.

I remember last yeat of having met in a train de Luxe an American gentleman with his lady and a young lady. The former was persuing a railway timetable. Nearly during the whole of the journey be critised in a most shameful way the wording of the names of the stations therein included. My whole blood rushed into my face and so vehement, I became that for the respect of his skin I would have run at him. However, I succeeded, and no sooner I explained to him with studied polite manners how the Anglo-French matter of affairs stand in this country; that it takes some time before the sole English language would be definitely installed all round. Of his criticisms I mention the most important one, where he said there are no Britishers employed in the railways and if these really exist they are of such a low class and breed that if donkeys would be put in their stead they would cut a beter figure. He was talking of the fine donkeys he saw in this country before he produced the time table. Undoubtly his lady and co. burst a loud laugh and boisterously, and it was here that I intrudded.

My intention of writing to you this time is to attract the attention of that offical in charge of the Department where timetables and names of stations are issued. Perhaps it would be better that a brother or a kin or another Mr. Dunlop be installed there.
Believe me, Dear sir, Yours faithfully, A friend of Mr. Dunlop
CairoOctober 18

div.head: THR PORT SAID INCIDENT.
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette"

Sir- By the present I desire to endorse the opinion of your correspondent "Cairene" regarding the dastardly assault on an Englishwoman at Port-Said by a guide. Accepting the report of your Port-Said correspondent as accurate in detail it is indeed a disgrace to the British community of that town that the man is again at work (to repeat such crimes, doubtless) and in good health. In the event of no action being taken by the authorities, the British community, had it been worthy of the greatest nation of the world, woud have taken the law into their own hands and administered the severest thrashing to the blackguard, and would have refused to allow him to continue work in any way dealing with the public. Also, what have the so-called British community done as regards the owner of the shop! -Yours truly
Alexandrian and Britisher
Alexandria, October 24

div.head: A TASTEFUL HANDBOOK ON EGYPT
div.p: "Things seen in Egypt", by Mr. Clive Holland, which Messrs Seely & Co. have been just published will, we think, be found a very acceptable volume by visitors to Egypt during the ensuing season. It contains a brightly written, and not too wordy, description of the varied features found here, with carefully summarised acounts of the historical objects. The author, it is quite evident, fell uner the spell of the country, and his language is that of the enthusiast. He becomes someone melancholy when referring to the many changes which the introduction of western ideas has b brought, but we cannot agree when he says that, in common with the old order of things, the spirit of Egypt will in time pass away. In the towns modern conditions may supplant ancient customs, but the old world spirit of the Land of the Pharaohs will remain

The "innovations" are the envitiable counter part of a new regime which has brought in its train untold blessings for the people of Egypt. From the aesthetic standpoint they may be regretted, in the same waythat Englishmen refer to the "good old days", the actual reutrn to which they would be the last to desire
The book is of a handy size, nicely bound, and is illustrated with fifty excellent photographs. It is published at 2/-

div.head: Crime in Egypt
div.p: The native Press is devoting a great deal of discussion to the subject of the increase of crime in Egypt "Al Watan" remarks

We find with the most profound degree that Egypt has become a notable exception so the rule of nations through the ever increasing number of crime year after year. Even India which is now practically in a state of unrest amounting to a serious mutiny shows an improvement and cannot be considered as marching onward in its criminal career. So far Russia which has been for many years undergoing a revolutionary upheaval showing signs of a slow return to the normal conditions of social life. But Egypt is still on the high road to anarchy and ruin. Who does not remember this fact without a pang of sorrow and regret.

There are so many reasons to this calmity that we can refer to one each time we write on this subject. The inefficiency of the Parquet stands, of course, first and foremost by the admission of every newspaper and every thinking expert in the country. But among the secondary causes for this growth in criminal tendencies the treatment of prisoners may be a very important one. Here we seem to be bent upon helping all prisoners to become criminals of the desperate class by our unique system of housing all offenders under the same roof and treating them all in the same manner. We have no difference between a political offender or a misguided miscreant and the murder or foriegner as far as the treatment of prisoners is concerned. Compare our prison system in this respect with the English system and you will at once understand why the present crisis in Egypt is growing in horror from day to day. The other day Mr. Wallace, K.C. made the following statements at the opening of the Clerkewell Sessions

"I am happy to say", he said, "that there has been a general diminution in crime. Some 20,000 fewer persons were sent to prison in the last tweleve months than in the previous year. That is a matter of crongratulation for every law abiding subject in thr kingdom"

"One of the causes is the great effort made to prevent first offenders sinking into the ranks of hardened criminals. Instead of persons being sent to gaol which often develops them into criminals, they have been assisted to start again, and many of them have become reputable citizens".

"The Probation of First Offenders Act", he continued "extends the power of the courts in the direction in which they have been endeavouring, as far as possible, to act. Power is now to be given to all courts, not merely to bind prisoners over to come up for judgement, but also to make special orders in regard to them"

"An instance is the appointment of what I may call a judicial guardian, a probation officer, whose duty it will be to watch over those bound over, to advise and help them and, if possible to obtain work for the. The greatest difficulty of many of those appearing in the dock is that it is almost impossible for them to get honest employment when the stigma of crime has been attched to them.
"From the beginning of next year every court will have an officer attached to it whose duty it will be to visit and report with regard to first offender"

Seeing that our prisoners are huddled together and that the habitual criminals are allowed to imbue those who are sentenced to prison for the first time with their own wrtehced principles, and remembering the fact that many an innocent person is here sent to prison tgrough the notorious defects of our judicial system and the deplorable ineffeciency of those who administer justice, is it wonderful that our criminals grow in audacity and numbers from year to year

div.head: MUNICIPALITE D'ALEXANDRIE
div.p: AVIS

Le jour de Samedi, 26 Octobre 1907, la Munictpalité prooédere a la vente aux enchéres publiques d'une quantité de pierres provenant de la démolition du Jardin Frangais et ce a l'emplacement du dit Jardin.
Les pierres sont diviedes en lots de 20 a 100 m.3.

Les acheteurs devront payer le droit d'en chére de 1% et déposer le 10% de la valuer de la marhcandise achetée au moment de la vente et effectuer le paiement intégral a la Caisse Municipale le lendemain du jour de l'Adjudication

Ils auront a supporter les droits de carriéres au profit de la ville et devront enlever les pierres achetées dans un délai de dix jours sous peine de folle enchére pour compte de l'adjudicataire et sous perte du dépot de 10%
La Municipalité est libres de ne pas donner suite a l'adjudication quels que soient les prix offerts
Le Vice-Président (Signé) Dr. Schiest Alexandrie, le 21 Octobre 1907

div.head:
THE RAILWAY CRISIS.
A CHAIRMAN'S MANIFESTO

div.p: The Chairman of the Great Eastern Railway ina manifesto absolutely refuses to recognise the Amalgamated Society of Railway Servants He says that most of the employés are non unionists and desire to be protected from the tyranny of an irresponsible body. He deolares that the demand for recognition is the first move in a deep laid socialistic campaign against individaalism and capital. (Reuter)

It is generally assomed that the manifesto of the Great Eastern Railway represents the decision of the Companies as a whole. Mr. Bell complains that it has made the position of Mr Lloyd George most awkward if he desires to offer conciliatory proposals. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE CALABRIA EARTHQUAKE
COLLAPSE OF A CATHEDRAL.
THE POPE'S GRIEF

div.p: The earthquake in Calabria has caused wide. spread damage and a general panic. A number of people have been killed or injured. The authorities are despatching assistance to the stricken towns and villages

Later reports show that many villages in Calabria have been ruined or balt ruined. The ancient cathedral of Gerace, containing works of art, collapsed during the earthquake. The Pope was moch grieved at the news and is sending money for the homeless. (Reuter)

Seismic shocks were felt yesterday through ont Calabria, caasing a great panic and much destruction. Feruzzano has been destroyed. It is reckoned that 200 persons have been killed and 400 injured. (Hares)

div.head:
NEW YORK CRISIS
MR. CORTELYOU TO THE RESCUE

div.p: Mr. Cortelyou, Secretary of the Treasury has arrived here to endeavour to rpstore conti dence regarding the financial situation, He conferred with the bankers and issued a state ment that the Treasury would use ita facilities to assiat legitimate businexs He declared that the position of the National Banks was excep tionally strong. It is stated that the Trust Company of America has already been granted liberal assistance and ba~ 12,000,000 dollars to meet its payments to day (Reuter)

Mr. Cortelyou deposited 10,040,000 dollar, with the local banks to-day. This steadied the market which closed active and irregular The Trust Company of Auerica successfully withstood the run upon it until closing The situation here is little short of a pane The Knickerbocker Trust Co. will suspen: payments until an official examination of it position has been completed. (Reuter)
Receivers have heen appointed for the West ing House Electric and Westing House Ma chine Companies.
The Stock Exchange hax been closed at the request of the local clearing house, (Renters)

The Presidents of the New York Trust Com panies have appointed a committee similar t. the hank and clearing house to assist com panies in applying for help. Mr. Pierpont Morgan will co-operate with them. Mr. Rocke teller has arranged to lend largely to financial Instititions
The Hamilton Bank with deposits of 7,000,000 dollars, the Twelftward Kank with deposits of 3,000,000 and the Empire and City Savings Bank with deposits of 3,300,000 (4m) hiny suspended payment.

Runs contuine the Dollar Savings Hank and Trust Company of America but all de mands have been met. The market pene strong and buoyant on the intervention of th: big financiers, but later relapsed below v0 terday's prices. (Renter)

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN ELEPHANT
div.p: One of the most remarkable dicoveries in paleontology of recent years has been the solution of the problem of the orgin of the elephant and a great deal of intrest therfore attches to the recent discovery in the Fayoum of the "beast of Lake Mocris", the Meritherium which represens ts the very at of transtion from an ordinary typical mammal into the nascent form of an elephant, and the Paleimastodon, the direct forerunner of the elephants. In teh year 1899 paleontology had advanced to such a point that the orgin of many families was known, but there remained in doubt the group of elephants, certainly the most paradoxical in structure of all the quadrupeds, and appearing in the Lower Miocane period, both in Europe and North America, fully formed, as if from teh sky or by a flat of the Creator. No one knew whence they came nor how their remarkable charcters had evolved. There were great unexplored regions in Asia ; the history of Chine was unknown ; and many writers were looking to the Orient for an answer to this question.

Mr. Henry Osborn, an American, in the year 1900 ventared on a prophecy which the original home of the elephants and of several other great groups in Africa At the time it seemed a curious fact that this theater of evolution of mammals had not sefficiently considered. Following the initial suggestions of Huxley, most writers were talk- ing of the invasion of Africa from the north by animals of European or Asiatic orgin, and few seemed to have in mind the possibility of a reversed current; namely, of the invasion of Europe Asia, and North America by animal orginating in Africa.

According to this theory of Mr. Osborn's Atrica in early geological times was a great centre of independent evolution , that, after its long isolation by the sea, when the trans- Mediterranean land routes were formed, suc cessive waves of animals migrated northward and poured into Europeand Asia, driven oat, perhaps, as man is driven out, by surplas popalation ; that there seemed tobe evidence in Europe of three such chief waves of life from Africa , and that promineut among the quadrupeds were the mastodons, ancestors of the great family of elephants.
Thus, if the paleontology of Africa could be- come known, the problem of the origin of the elephants might be solved.

So long ago as 1879, the German explorer Schweinfarth had obtained in the Payoum desert some bones of the great whalelike animal named Zeaglodon, which swam along the Mediterranean shores during the Eocene period. In 189% came the first evidence of the existence of land animals, and im 1901, when Mr Beadnell was accompanied by Dr C W Andrews of the British Maseum, the dissovery land animals ia the Fayoum desert was an nounced It has proved to be epoch making, marking a torning-point in our knowledge ot the Instory of the earth, and aronsing such wide-spread interest that for the time north Africa becomes the stormoentre ot paleon tology Between 1901 and 1905 the explora tion and collection of these fossils continued under Messrs Beadnell and Andrews One unexpected discovery succeeded — another Africa, far from being a continent parasitic upon Europe, was proved to be a partly de pendent, but chiefly independent centre of a highly varied lite ,a great breeding-place not only of animals which subseqnently wandered into Europe, but of animals belonging to types hitherto unknown and andreamed of

At the beginning of thts year Mo Osborn arrived at Alexandna in charge of a mission deapatched by the American Museum of Natural History and in this mooth's "Century Magazine' he gives description of the work of the expedition in the Payoum.
EGYPT 200,000 YEARS AGO
The expedition was very successful in its itiscoveries of relics of the Palaemastodon and the Moeritherium. Mr. Osborn gives the follow ing pictore of Eocene Egypt 200,000 years ago

We believe from evidence of many different kinds that all ot North Africa at that remote time was comparatively well watered ; chiefly hecanse our present glimpses of the life, as known from the fossilized remains, included no desert living animals whatever, but exclusively animals which might have lived in a fairly weil watered delta or estuary country bordering the sea, partly open, partly wooded, bat not densely forested, with stretches of sandy plains ot muddy and clayey bottom-lands traversed by large streams, with currents of considerable velocity. As Beadnell observes, the enormous quantities of silicified wood which occur among these sands, and the hundreds of trees of great length and girth, together with the numerous remains of land animals as well as of crocodiles, tartles, and tortoises, indicate that rivers of considerable size emerged from the land to the south. While the trunks of the trees may have been floated a long distance, for the branches are all torn off, the pertect contours of the bones of the animals prove that they had not been transported very far

The country was certainly not heavily forested, however, because the close proximity of the sea, as well as the number of very large animals, precludes the existence of a continous and densely tropical forest in the immediate environment. Large quadrupeds cannot find food in the shade of a dense forest , they need the food which is developed on the ground by sonlight. Even now in the thick forests of

© Haunting the Ancestral Elephant im the Fayoum Dewrt Discoveries of the Recent African Expedition of the American Museem of Natural History By Henry Pairfield Osborn. Da Costa Professor of Zoology, Columbia University, Curator of Vertebrate Paleontology, Americas Museum of Natural History in charge of the expedition with pictures from photo grephs and restorations by Charles B. Knight. the Congo both the hippopotamus and the elephant are dwarfed in size as compared with those of eastern Africa

We judge of the nature of the soil from the structure of the limbs and feet. In constrast with the finely drawn limbs of the desert animals of modern Libya, the animals of Eocene Libya had feet fitted for walking on soft if not moist and sinking ground. Thus the soil of the period was certainly not dry hard, although it was partly sandy. There are, however, some evidence of the proximity of the great stretches of dry land because we ind giant land tortoises (Testudo ammon, named after the Egyptian god Ammon) resembling those of Madagascar. There were also giant pythons (Gigantophis) thrity feet in length. There were ostrich-like birds, but they have been partly forest dwellers, like the emus of New Zealand

So far, therefore, as animals mirror their surroundings. Eocene Libya was a savannah country, partly open, partly thicketed or jungled, partly forested, of about the same temperature as to-day, fairly well watered, and subject to occasional freshets and floodings from the south. Such a general picture of the landscape may at least be drawn from the discoveries of the Egyptian Survey
THE FAYOUM ELEPHANTS MARCH

The world wide march of the Egyptian Elephant trom its old home began in the lower Miocene and Pticapne when Africa ceased to be a great island and the elevation of the bottom of the Mediterranean Sea formed one land bridge after another, and the great exodus from peot-up Africa began. The sea-cows, the giant conies, the mastodons, and several other African autochthones entered Europe in great numbers.

What the results would have been if the elephants had been released from Atrica in an earlier stage of evolution can only be guessed at, but that they were superbly equipped for foreign travel and conquest when they actual ly did emerge is absolutely demonstrate! As secure as the Romans with their phalanxes and their legions, these quadfapeds marched over one or other of the land bridges as soon as they were formed. They saddenly appeared in the Lower Miocene of Europe in the vicinity of modern Paria The race spread so fast and maltiplied so rapidly in the Northern Hemis phere that in the Middle Miocene they reached the geographical point in North America now known as eastern Colorado By the upper Mhorene, or perhaps earlier, they were foand in Texas and Mexico. Most opportunely in the Lower Pliocene the Isthmus of Panama rose out of the sea, connecting North and South America, which had been separated for an enor mously long penod, and the mastodons invad ed South Amenca, and, following the line of the Andes, pushed as far south as the Pampaan region

As time went on, the elephants began to evolve and replace the mastodons in vanous parts of the world Their geographical range, which extended from the British Isles all over Europe, along the northern shores of Siberia, into Texas and Mexico, is equally marvelous. In the whole history of creation no other animal, with the single exception of the horse, accomplished soch feats of travel

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET.
div.p: Kranstry and Cunningham's Wekkly Report
Liverpool,October 17
There is no improvement in the demand for Spot Egyptians. Spinner« continue to buy from hand to month and qnotations of Brown are reduced 1/18, and uppers 1/18 @ 2/18 plh. for the week.
In Futures, a fairly active business has been put through; and the following are the latest quotations

American Futures The Market opened this week rather depressed and weak, showing that the predicted frost ables had failed _ the "Bearixh" character of some of the private cables, together with a sharp break in the New York and New Orleans markets had rather a depressing influence Towards the middle of the week light frosts were reported from the Memphis districts, and some sections of Ala hams and Arkansas, which, together with some large orders supposed ty he for Conti nental account, put up prices. The improve ment was not of long duration however, for cables reporting warmer weather caused a collapse, and the market closes quiet at 4 points advance for near, and 11 points decline for distant, on the week.

It is very difficult to gauge the situation , for juat now the financial position in many countries is in such an unsettled state. The crop news is generally considered satisfactory, but actual cotton is not being offered freely

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: Instructions have been issued to push recruiting for the Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers —the 1st Battalion of which ie in Crete, and the 2nd Battalion, at Cairo—thronghout the North Ifish Grouped Regimental District.

Major A.G Fraser has just retired from the 2nd Battalion King's Own Scottish Borders, Glaagow, after spending nearly 20 years in the service. He was with the Borders in the Chitral Campaign, 1895, was attached to the Egyptian Amry for some time, shared in the Nile Expedition, 1898, including the battle of Khartoum, and commanded a im the Ist Battalion during the South African War.

The vacant majority has gone to Captain D. R. Sladen D.S.O., adjutant of 1st Volunteer Battalion, Melrose, an appointment which he now vacates. Major Sladen gets his spurs at a little over 19 years' service, and he has seen a lot of active service in the Soudan, 1888-89, North West Frontiers of India, 1897-98 in the cdurse of which he was wounded, and earned his decoration , and with the 1st Battalion in Sonth Africa he was present st nomerous actions, including those of Peardeberg, Poplar Grove, Karee Siding, Vet River, Zand River, Johannesburg Pretoria and Zilikat's Nek.
It has been ordered that the recruits enlisted for the 6th Inniskilling Dragoons, Cairo, must be between the agen of 19 and 25, except in the cases of boys.

It is stated that field marshal's baton will be conferred by the King on Sir John Prench he vacates tl Aldershot Command next month. Sir John is not the senior of his rank, Lord Kitebener, lord Grenfell, Lord Methcen, Sir Archibald Hunter and many other distinguish. ed soldiers taking precedence and seniority of him. Of course this would mean the passing over of these distinguished officers for the time being, bat there ix a precedent for that in the cuases of Sir George White, VC, and Sir Evelyn Wool, VC The senior general on the active list is Lord Kitchener of Khartoam, the Indian Commander in Chief

The first Alans battleship "Goliath," whieh is undergoing a thoroagh refit at Portemouth at an authorised expenditare of £48,419, is to be realy for the pennant by the end of Janaary next. Her sister battleship "Canopus," which will be taken in hand at Portsmooth neat month, and a sum of £25,498 expended apon her, is to be ready for sea by the end of March. | Both these battleships are destined for the Mediterranean Pleet, in which they will replace the two "Formidables" in accordance with the decision of the Admiralty already announced in these notes The "Goliath" was completed for sea in 1900, and was commissioned in that year for service on the China Station, on which she spent three years. Returning bome in 1903, she was again commissioned by Captain Kingsford in June, 1905, for another turn on the same station, she was recalled whilst at Colombo, and seot to the Mediterranean Fleet, with which she served till January 1906, when she was transferred to the Fleet. The "Canopus" spent her maiden commission on the Mediterranean Station, 1899-1908, and she, too, was on her way to the China Station, along with the "Goliath," when she was re-called for service with the Atlantic Pleet, June, 1905. The ships of the "Canopus" typearse smaller than | the "Formidables," and their armamentis not so strong, but they havea slight advantage in the matter of speed. The "Cioliath" and "Canopus" will be manned by 750 of all ranks as private sbipa. In service circles, the weakening of the battle squastron of the Mediterranean leet by the withdrawal of the "Furmidables" does not meet with unqualified approval

Vice Admiral Sir Arthar W Moore, K CB, KCVO. CMG, commanding the China Squadron and the Eastern Fleet, has just been promoted to the rank of admiral Admiral Moore has had a distingnished career since he joined the senior service as acadet nearly 47 years ago, and his services in that period have been many and varied. He was commander of the battleship "Orion" during the Egyptian War, 1882, was at the occupation of Ismailia, and subsequently commanded the flotilla on the Sweet Water canal for the conveyance of the sick and wounded, participated in the battle of Tel el Kebir and other affairs (mentioned in despatches, medal with clasp, Khedive's star, 3rd class Medijideh and promoted captain): was one of the British representatives at the Anti-Slavery Congress, Brussels, 1889; rendered very valuable service in the preperation of a scheme of defence for Australasia, 1892 (C.M.G.); was A.D.C, to the Queen, 1895; was given the C.B at teh Diamond Jubilee, and commanded the Cape Squadron during the latter phases of the Boer War, his services in that direction earning for him the best thanks of Lord Kitchener, and the K.C.B. SIr Arthur will vacate the command of the China Squadron on promotion to full flag rank
